content: I fully believe that a lack of purpose, a sense of having no worth, is what kills most men within 5 years of retirement. As men, we tend to identifiy ourselves by what we do for a living, unlike women who identify themselves by their relationships, and when we are no longer doing anything of value, we come to the erroneous conclusion that we have no value either. That almost inevitably leads to a slow, incremental loss of the will to live. I believe we can will ourselves into the grave if we're not careful. So, what to do about that? Get out and get involved in others peoples lives. Not directly by going next door and telling your neighbor how to live his life, but through charitable work which interests you. Retirement is a great time to take an inventory of yourself and, if you do it honestly, you'll find that you have interests and skills which you never knew you had or which you put on the back burner through your working life. At least, that's how it worked for me. I found that I could paint, for instance. That's a skill I never knew I had and enjoyed putting brush to canvas. Eventually, I found my way into disaster relief with the Southern Baptist's and that's given me a whole new identity, a whole new focus and it's been the best thing which ever happened to me. Yes, I'm still physically able to do that, but there are many, many who do it alongside me who are disabled. Even some in wheelchairs or really advanced age. They can be found doing administrative work or even something as simple as handing out bottles of water at a feeding unit. The point is that no matter the disability or the restricitions we find ourselves working with in old age, we can still find some useful work to do IF we're looking and IF we don't just sit down and amuse ourselves until we die.

That almost inevitably leads to a slow, incremental loss of the will to live. I believe we can will ourselves into the grave if we're not careful. So, what to do about that? Get out and get involved in others peoples lives. Not directly by going next door and telling your neighbor how to live his life, but through charitable work which interests you. Retirement is a great time to take an inventory of yourself and, if you do it honestly, you'll find that you have interests and skills which you never knew you had or which you put on the back burner through your working life. At least, that's how it worked for me. I found that I could paint, for instance. That's a skill I never knew I had and enjoyed putting brush to canvas. Eventually, I found my way into disaster relief with the Southern Baptist's and that's given me a whole new identity, a whole new focus and it's been the best thing which ever happened to me. Yes, I'm still physically able to do that, but there are many, many who do it alongside me who are disabled. Even some in wheelchairs or really advanced age. They can be found doing administrative work or even something as simple as handing out bottles of water at a feeding unit. The point is that no matter the disability or the restricitions we find ourselves working with in old age, we can still find some useful work to do IF we're looking and IF we don't just sit down and amuse ourselves until we die.
title: Getting Off

content: We have plenty of work to do around the 10 acres. Dennis is always having to repair something. Still need to finish the outside of the house on the second level, it needs trim done. Need someone to do it for us cause I won't get up there and neither will Denns. It's funny Dennis can repel out of a chopper but he won't get on the house, lol. Plus it takes money to do what we really want to do around here. Would love a pipe fence, but that will have to wait till we win the lottery. Right now Dennis either has a head cold or has a bad sinus infection and he feels like shi at. I just tell him not to worry about anything, just stay drugged up till he gets better.

content: quote: Originally posted by stillkit: . . . .Yes, I'm still physically able to do that, but there are many, many who do it alongside me who are disabled. Even some in wheelchairs or really advanced age. They can be found doing administrative work or even something as simple as handing out bottles of water at a feeding unit. The point is that no matter the disability or the restricitions we find ourselves working with in old age, we can still find some useful work to do IF we're looking and IF we don't just sit down and amuse ourselves until we die. very well said Kit!! I’m not retired yet. Do I spend too much time here? Maybe. BUT look around; there is a GREAT group of people here!! Many are heroes in my book. Some I’ve met personally, some I may never meet. Doesn’t matter; from around the world we’ve all come together!! I’ve laughed, I’ve cried and I’ve prayed with many here. We’re all on this earth for each other. choose joy each day

title: Getting Off

content: As usual Kit, I concur with you (almost) completely! I've seen far too many people lose their will to live when they perceive that they no longer have purpose! In my opinion, so long as you are drawing breath, you have at least that purpose, then you just need to fill the hours in a fashion that seems (at least to yourself) positive and constructive. Of course, this belief may simply be a function of the fact that I'm not yet 55, am still pretty healthy (downright vibrant compared to most of my peers) and active, and have not only family and a business to occupy my time, but more interests than ever before in my life. This with the realization that I likely haven't sufficient years left to persue all of my interests so, yes! I probably spend far too much time on these (and other) fora, but it's a good place to meet with like (and unlike) minded people for discussion of opinions and the sharing of information and heck, let's face it! It's a great place to get in a good old-fashioned donnybrook if only in it's virtual form (though no where as vociferous and bloodletting as only a few years ago) and most who have shared the Military lifestyle enjoy this kind of activity! It's in our blood! Damn! I gotta get busy! I've a lot to accomplish today and I've only been at it for about five hours now! It is not our belief or disbelief that can make or unmake the fact. ~ Thomas Paine

content: quote: Originally posted by RetiredMarineWife: We have plenty of work to do around the 10 acres. Dennis is always having to repair something. Still need to finish the outside of the house on the second level, it needs trim done. Need someone to do it for us cause I won't get up there and neither will Denns. It's funny Dennis can repel out of a chopper but he won't get on the house, lol. Plus it takes money to do what we really want to do around here. Would love a pipe fence, but that will have to wait till we win the lottery. Right now Dennis either has a head cold or has a bad sinus infection and he feels like shi at. I just tell him not to worry about anything, just stay drugged up till he gets better. I built a sucker rod fence for my dad. I used a few joints of old 2" tubing for the posts and some old sucker rod that was no longer usable. I got both for just hauling it off from an oil company's abandoned glycol plant. Being I knew who owned it, I just called them up and asked their price of the old stuff. They said it would suffice to just haul it off and keep them from having to do it. If you guys look around, you may find something similar. Maybe even find an abandoned pipe yard and do it all in pipe as you want. (Just don't use drill stem!) LOL

content: quote: Originally posted by stillkit: . . . .Yes, I'm still physically able to do that, but there are many, many who do it alongside me who are disabled. Even some in wheelchairs or really advanced age. They can be found doing administrative work or even something as simple as handing out bottles of water at a feeding unit. The point is that no matter the disability or the restricitions we find ourselves working with in old age, we can still find some useful work to do IF we're looking and IF we don't just sit down and amuse ourselves until we die. very well said Kit!! I’m not retired yet. Do I spend too much time here? Maybe. BUT look around; there is a GREAT group of people here!! Many are heroes in my book. Some I’ve met personally, some I may never meet. Doesn’t matter; from around the world we’ve all come together!! I’ve laughed, I’ve cried and I’ve prayed with many here. We’re all on this earth for each other. choose joy each day

title: Getting Off

content: As usual Kit, I concur with you (almost) completely! I've seen far too many people lose their will to live when they perceive that they no longer have purpose! In my opinion, so long as you are drawing breath, you have at least that purpose, then you just need to fill the hours in a fashion that seems (at least to yourself) positive and constructive. Of course, this belief may simply be a function of the fact that I'm not yet 55, am still pretty healthy (downright vibrant compared to most of my peers) and active, and have not only family and a business to occupy my time, but more interests than ever before in my life. This with the realization that I likely haven't sufficient years left to persue all of my interests so, yes! I probably spend far too much time on these (and other) fora, but it's a good place to meet with like (and unlike) minded people for discussion of opinions and the sharing of information and heck, let's face it! It's a great place to get in a good old-fashioned donnybrook if only in it's virtual form (though no where as vociferous and bloodletting as only a few years ago) and most who have shared the Military lifestyle enjoy this kind of activity! It's in our blood! Damn! I gotta get busy! I've a lot to accomplish today and I've only been at it for about five hours now! It is not our belief or disbelief that can make or unmake the fact. ~ Thomas Paine

title: Getting Off

content: quote: Originally posted by RetiredMarineWife: We have plenty of work to do around the 10 acres. Dennis is always having to repair something. Still need to finish the outside of the house on the second level, it needs trim done. Need someone to do it for us cause I won't get up there and neither will Denns. It's funny Dennis can repel out of a chopper but he won't get on the house, lol. Plus it takes money to do what we really want to do around here. Would love a pipe fence, but that will have to wait till we win the lottery. Right now Dennis either has a head cold or has a bad sinus infection and he feels like shi at. I just tell him not to worry about anything, just stay drugged up till he gets better. I built a sucker rod fence for my dad. I used a few joints of old 2" tubing for the posts and some old sucker rod that was no longer usable. I got both for just hauling it off from an oil company's abandoned glycol plant. Being I knew who owned it, I just called them up and asked their price of the old stuff. They said it would suffice to just haul it off and keep them from having to do it. If you guys look around, you may find something similar. Maybe even find an abandoned pipe yard and do it all in pipe as you want. (Just don't use drill stem!) LOL

Maybe even find an abandoned pipe yard and do it all in pipe as you want. (Just don't use drill stem!) LOL
